title: 104_hr4110
content: The "Children Health Insurance Act of 1996" requires health insurance availability for children through amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This includes provisions for excise tax on failure to meet coverage requirements and definitions related to access to coverage. A tax is imposed on group health plans and insurers for failing to meet coverage requirements. The tax amount is 25 percent of premiums received for the plan year. Self-insured plans treat the cost of coverage as premiums. Insurers offering individual health insurance are also subject to the tax. The tax imposed on insurers for failing to meet coverage requirements is 25 percent of premiums paid for individual health insurance. The tax does not apply if the failure was not discovered despite reasonable diligence or if the failure is corrected within 30 days due to reasonable cause and not willful neglect. The tax imposed on insurers for failing to meet coverage requirements can be waived if the failure is corrected within 30 days and was not due to willful neglect. The tax does not apply to governmental or church plans. The responsible parties for the tax are the group health plan or the insurer. The tax imposed on insurers offering health insurance coverage can be waived if the failure to meet coverage requirements is corrected within 30 days and was not due to willful neglect. The responsible party for the tax is the insurer. "SEC. 9902. REQUIREMENT OF ACCESS TO COVERAGE." Each group health plan must offer qualifying coverage for qualifying young dependents of participants. The offer must be made when a person first becomes a qualifying young dependent and annually thereafter. Health insurers in the individual market must offer qualifying coverage for individuals under 21 years old who are US citizens or residents. Qualifying coverage includes health care benefits without limitations based on pre-existing conditions. The existing condition for benefits includes Medicare benefits under parts A and B of title XVIII of the Social Security Act, or equivalent benefits. Well child care benefits cover newborn and well-baby care without deductibles or coinsurance. The benefits described in the section include normal newborn care, pediatrician services for high-risk deliveries, well-child care, routine office visits, immunizations, laboratory tests, preventive dental care, and a periodicity schedule established by the Secretary in consultation with the American Academy of Pediatrics. Managed care is permitted for the provision of these benefits. The term 'qualifying young dependent' refers to an individual under 21 years old, residing in the US, a citizen or national (or alien permanently residing in the US under color of law), and a dependent as defined in section 152. "SEC. 9903. DEFINITIONS." "In this chapter, the term 'group health plan' is defined as per section 5000(b)(1), excluding plans with medical benefits limited to coverage in paragraph (2)(B). 'Health insurance coverage' refers to benefits for medical care under various policies or contracts, excluding coverage for accident or credit-only policies." The curr_chunk outlines various types of insurance coverage, including accident, vision, disability income, long-term care, liability insurance, workers' compensation, and automobile medical-payment insurance. The curr_chunk discusses different types of insurance coverage, such as automobile medical-payment insurance, coverage for specified diseases, hospital indemnity insurance, short-term limited duration insurance, and other comparable coverage as specified in regulations. It also defines a health maintenance organization as a federally qualified organization, one recognized under state law, or a similar organization regulated for solvency under state law. The curr_chunk defines key terms related to insurance, such as insurer, individual market, and incorporation of certain definitions. These terms are crucial for understanding the regulations surrounding insurance coverage. The curr_chunk adds definitions for 'beneficiary' and 'participant' from the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The curr_chunk introduces a refundable tax credit for the purchase of health coverage for children, effective from January 1, 1998, regardless of the plan year start date. The individual is eligible for a tax credit of 80% of qualified health premiums paid in the taxable year. The credit is applied against tax liability at a rate of $0.50 for each $1 of tax liability, with tax liability defined as the excess of the tax imposed for the year over the credit allowed under section 32. The term 'social security taxes' refers to taxes imposed on income received by the taxpayer, including taxes on self-employment income and amounts received during the taxable year. Coordination with special refund of social security taxes is also mentioned. The term 'social security taxes' excludes taxes eligible for special refund under section 6413(c). Amounts paid under agreements with foreign affiliates are treated as taxes. Definitions include 'qualified health premium' for young dependents' health coverage. The term 'social security taxes' excludes taxes eligible for special refund under section 6413(c). Amounts paid under agreements with foreign affiliates are treated as taxes. Definitions include 'qualified health premium' for young dependents' health coverage. Amendment made to the table of sections for subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1997.
